title: Discovering Concept Coverings in Aligning Ontologies of Linked Data

author: Rahul Parundekar, University of Southern California

segmentation: Hi, my name is Ronald and I will be talking about designing discovering concept, covering, Zan aligning ontologies of linked data.
So on the web of linked data that are different sources an each of these sources have different schema.
Now, equivalent instances in these sources are linked together with the owl same as relationship.
For example, in the geospatial domain you have DP pedia linked with geonames or you have linked your data linked with Geo names.
So intellect instance.
This.
Have disjoint schemas.
For example, if you look at the instance level, you would see that.
Los Angeles is linked to the City of Los Angeles.
Well, at the concept level.
There's no links present, and that's a problem.
The problem is that there are disconnected ontologies.
Only a small number of these ontologies are linked.
Existing concepts in these ontologies might not be sufficient because of because these ontologies are created from RDBMS.
For the interoperability goal of the semantic Web.
Alignments are necessary.
So our solution is to generate alignments using linked data.
We use an extensional approach.
Where we use set theory to say if there are two sets of classes, we try to figure out if there is an overlap and determine if there is.
There's a concept covering or not.
So if for two instance set if they overlap then we can say they are equivalent or we can say that one is subset of another.
In aligning rustr.
In classes using extensional approach we have the following things.
So let's say in one of the class you have.
An extension set or a class created by fixing the value of the property feature class as P and on the other side you have.
Another class where the value for the property RDF type is populated.
Place so now we go ahead and compare these two sets.
And once we figure out whether they overlap perfectly, we can say that these guys are equal.
But there is a pattern to be explored in.
Subset relationships.
Let's look at three of the subset.
Be fun.
First schools in June names are educational institutions and EPD.
Second colleges in geonames.
Our educational institutions and EPD.
And third, universities in Geonames are educational institutions and deep.
Yeah.
Now taken by themselves, these are not that useful.
But
What we can do is we can using the feature code property as a hint, we can form a union of concepts so you can form a union of all of these three concepts to form a larger concept.
And now we can compare this large concept with the educational institution can't.
And we can find concept coverings by using an extensional comparison.
So that is the first contribution of our paper.
Now as a result I will explain some alignments that we got from DP aligning DB pedia, and geonames.
If you look at the table, we had larger concept from educational institution from DB pedia and we had the smaller concepts from geonames like school universities and colleges.
So 396 of these instances agree with this assertion and this is out of total 404 instances.
So the rest of the eight instances we were also able to identify where these actually went.
So we identified these as outliers.

As another example, we were also able to align Spain from DB Pedia with Spain from Geonames, but the problem was there was one single instance which was classified as having the property country as Italy in Geonames and that is an outlier that we are also able to detect.
So that's the second contribution of our work.
So to summarize, we found around 7000 alignments, including outliers, for five pairs of sources, and these belongs to three different domains.
Sergio spatial domain, the zoologie domain, and the genetics domain.
Totally, there were 77,000 odd subset relationships and we were able to find 7000 alignments from this.
That's it, so if you have any.
Feel free to drop us an email.
Email addresses are mentioned on the screen.
Thank you.
